title-group.article-title: Assessing the spatial risk of wild birds in avian influenza transmission using global risk score

contrib-group.aff: 1https://ror.org/05vn3ca78grid.260542.70000 0004 0532 3749Department of Applied Mathematics and Graduate Institute of Statistics, National Chung Hsing University, Taichung, 402 Taiwan

abstract.p: Accumulated evidence supports the critical role of migratory wild birds in highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAIV) spread and evolution. An effective surveillance strategy to study HPAIV dispersal in wild birds and identify critical interfaces between wild birds and poultry on the landscape for potential interspecies transmission and virus evolution will be essential. This study integrates conditional likelihood with epidemiological research designs to investigate the risk of poultry farm outbreaks due to the introduction of HPAIV by migratory birds from the Taiwan citizen scientist dataset. The prediction accuracy of poultry farm outbreaks was evaluated by employing the global risk score (GRS) of multiple species of wild birds under different significance level. Although 11 wild bird species demonstrated significant associations (P < 0.05) with HPAIV poultry farm outbreaks, the bird species with P < 0.1 yielded the optimal area under the receiver operating characteristic curve. Without prior adjustment of environmental factors, the posterior adjusted likelihood results suggested that the agricultural wetlands yield notably strong positive odds ratio estimates for all species. The GRS under adjustment of environmental factors, a linear combination of the 27 migratory species and 27 resident species, was 0.320, yielding a sensitivity of 0.81 and specificity of 0.77. The framework of GRS developed in this study can be applied to different countries for enhanced surveillance of HPAIV.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1038/s41598-025-17678-8.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI), a zoonotic infectious disease, has been considered a severe threat to public health1. Periodically, human infections associated with HPAI virus (HPAIV) have been detected, in particular, by the Eurasian (goose/Guangdong/1996 [Gs/Gd]) lineage2,3. With the continued evolution and circulation of HPAIV, Gs/Gd lineage has been involved in multiple waves of global influenza epizootic outbreaks with genetically distinct virus clades and subclades4. In contrast to previous clades of Gs/Gd lineage, clade 2.3.4.4 showed more persistent spillovers to local domestic poultry, impacting the poultry farming industry with tremendous economic losses5,6. The emergence and transmission of clade 2.3.4.4 continue to provide virological, epidemiological, and ecological evidence in support of the critical role of migratory wild birds in HPAIV spread and evolution7–9. Therefore, developing a wild-bird risk score will assist in outbreak prediction as well as implementing targeted surveillance.

The challenge of studying HPAIV dispersal in wild birds is the lack of HPAIV prevalence and movement data10,11. The longitudinal studies documented the HPAIV prevalence in wild bird populations have been established in disparate geographical locations with related avian host ecology; however, such data cannot be easily generalized globally due to the constrain, mainly in low pathogenic influenza viruses in restricted locations such as Alaska12. On the contrary, a global systemic surveillance of HAPI will be ideal but not feasible due to resource constraints. Therefore, a research framework to design effective surveillance strategies to study HPAIV dispersal in wild birds and identify critical interfaces between wild birds and poultry across the landscape for potential interspecies transmission and virus evolution will be essential13.

Since many different wild bird species may be involved in HPAIV transmission, with varying levels of interaction with each other and poultry premises, citizen science initiatives, such as eBird, are capable of enhancing our understanding of species abundance and distributions without relying on any field- or laboratory-led surveillance to identify potential wild bird hosts, and can be rapidly deployed as a target surveillance system against pathogens with wild reservoirs of infection in areas with limited wild host testing capacity14. As the biases usually come along from semi-structured data collection procedures in collecting citizen science data, assessing species-level drivers of virus incursions into poultry flocks can be challenging, which requires advances in novel epidemiological approaches and analytical computation15–17.

Over the past ten years, bird flu outbreaks have occurred in Taiwan almost every year18,19. During this period, avian influenza virus can often be detected in the carcasses of dead migratory birds20,21. In this study, we proposed an analytical framework utilizing the Taiwan eBird dataset by integrating conditional likelihood with epidemiological research design, matching, and counter-matching, for estimation of the significance level of migratory bird species introducing HPAI into the poultry farms. The prediction accuracy of poultry farm outbreaks was evaluated by employing the global risk score (GRS) of multiple species of wild birds under different significance levels.

sec.title: Datasets and study time frame
sec.p: The main island of Taiwan was divided into 4,762 squares, each measuring 3 km by 3 km, to be consistent with our previous publication14,19 (as the example shown in Fig. 2). The time frame of this study was between January 2015 and December 2017, and the reason for choosing this time frame is due to the major HPAI poultry farm outbreaks in Taiwan since 2003, caused by the emergence of clade 2.3.4.4. The timeline is consistent with the poultry farm outbreaks globally. Based on the surveillance system in Taiwan, the outbreaks continued but became endemic with fewer outbreaks of poultry farms reported to the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ), Taiwan, after 201822. These grids were then integrated with the following datasets for modeling purposes, including:

list-item.label: (i)
list-item.p: eBird data and the derived propensity score estimating the likelihood of bird species distribution in each grid: Before constructing the wild bird distribution map, bird sighting records from the eBird citizen science database, Cornell University15,16were obtained for the selection of wild bird species relevant for the introduction of either HPAI or LPAI into the poultry farm. The data provides fine-scale occurrence data of bird species, bird-sighting GPS location, sampling effort, and duration based on observers’ traveling route and sampling protocol, and so on. The bird species showing breeding and wintering with preference to areas in Taiwan, and passing once or twice a year, may potentially act as a reservoir for LPAI, will thus be considered for selection. In the end, we restricted the number of wild bird species for analysis to 68. The inclusion criteria include (1) the top 20% abundance by ranking the counts from the checklists of the observers of the Taiwan eBird dataset; (2) the influenza virus isolation records from 3 databases: Influenza Virus Database, EMPRES-I, and Influenza Research Database before the date of 12/03/2020. We used the data reported between January 2015 and December 2017 to estimate the bird species distribution in each grid by propensity score through the zero-inflated Poisson (ZIP) model23. The details of wild bird species inclusion were described previously by Wu et al.14.

list-item.label: (ii)
list-item.p: Terrestrial and environmental data: Obtained from Taiwan’s Endemic Species Research Institute, this dataset comprises nine land-cover types, which include farmland (FL), dry farming (DF), agricultural wetland (AW), forest (FR), wetland (WL), urban (UB), waterbody (WB), bushes (BU), and bare land (BL)24.

list-item.label: (iii)
list-item.p: HPAIV outbreaks data: A total of 1,223 poultry farm outbreaks were reported to the surveillance system, during 2015–2017, established by BAPHIQ in Taiwan19.

list-item.label: (iv)
list-item.p: Poultry farm census dataset: The comprehensive poultry farm census dataset was acquired from the Council of Agriculture, Taiwan, through an island-wide survey that utilized remote satellite imaging technology, overseen by the Taiwan Agriculture Research Institute19.

sec.title: Epidemiological design and statistical analysis
Algorithm for making conditional likelihood inference
sec.p: The following steps were used to estimate the distribution for each bird species with the flowchart shown in Fig. 1.

caption.p: A flowchart of the research framework. A computational procedure is iteratively implemented for all selected different bird species. The propensity score (PS) matching is implemented by 1:m matching with m = 3 and 5; k refers to the k-th selected bird species, with k ranging from 1 to K = 68. ROC refers to the receiver operating characteristic curve.

sec.p: Step 1. For bird species (k) ranging from 1 to K, utilize the ZIP model to determine the association of each species (k), whether it is present or absent, based on the presence of all other species25. This is accomplished through the application of both Model (A1) and Model (A2), accounting for spatial correlation with details described in Appendix 1. In this step, Model (A3) elucidates the specific “propensity score” (PS) for each species (k). In brief, formula (A1) represents a logistic regression that accounts for spatial autocorrelation in the data structure, estimating the probability of a species being a ‘structural zero.’ Model (A2), using the same covariates as (A1), models the Poisson distribution to estimate the probability of a ‘sampling zero,’ reflecting the chance of non-observation. Finally, model (A3), which serves as the basis for matching, is used to derive the propensity score. During this step, the PSs are first estimated without adjustment for environmental factors, and then re-estimated with such adjustment. Figure 1 provides the flowchart of the estimation procedure, where adjustment for environmental factors is also possible at the step of constructing the conditional likelihood.

Step 2. A grid-specific propensity score (PS) is determined for the presence of species k for each case grid in Step 1. Subsequently, a subset of m control grids is selected from the nd available grids. These m control grids are chosen based on matching criteria in their PS values using the “nearest neighbor” score; or through counter-matching, which involves inverse sampling-probability weightings.

Step 3. Create a conditional likelihood function when the sole covariate is the presence-absence status, represented as a binary dummy variable, for species k. During this step, the parameter estimate for species k is derived through conditional likelihood inference.

In step 1, the practice of dichotomizing all risk variables is utilized to mitigate bias, albeit at the cost of some statistical efficiency. Moving to step 2, we apply the matching and counter-matching concept to rigorously control all other ‘risk factors’ collectively. Prior to reaching step 2, a variable selection procedure may be implemented when the number of adjustment variables is substantial. This includes techniques such as the ‘greedy orthogonal algorithm‘26 and the utilization of penalty-based information criteria27. Furthermore, in step 3, during conditional likelihood estimation, there is the option to treat the matching score as a risk factor or simply allow it to be matched out28–30.

sec.title: Conditional likelihood constructed by matching and countering matching
Matching

list-item.label: (i)
(ii)
list-item.p: Nearest-neighbor sub-sample: The “m” controls from the risk set with the closest propensity scores to the case grid were selected.

sec.title: Counter-matching with inverse probability weight
Prior and posterior adjustments for environmental factors
sec.p: When establishing the propensity score matching (PSM), the propensity scores can be estimated using two approaches: one that includes adjustment for environmental factors and one that does not. The results in Tables 1 and 2 correspond to these two cases. We refer to Table 2 as ‘prior adjustment.’ In this context, both Eqs. (1) and (2) do not include any environmental variables in the covariate vector x.

caption.p: Conditional likelihood estimates of significant species associated with AIV outbreaks without adjustment for environmental factors.

p.italic: a. Nsp, no. significant positive associations in 1,000 experiments.

table-wrap-foot.p: b. The term “nonsig” refers to results that are not statistically significant and are not included in this table.
c.* indicates a case of mild significance with 0.05 < p-value < 0.10.

caption.p: Conditional likelihood estimates of significant species associated with AIV outbreaks with prior adjustment for environmental factors.

table-wrap-foot.p: a. Nsp, no. significant positive associations in 1,000 experiments.
b. The term “nonsig” refers to results that are not statistically significant and are not included in this table.
c. * indicates a case of mild significance with 0.05 < p-value < 0.10.

sec.p: However, it’s possible to perform adjustment after establishing the PSM without adjustment by incorporating the environmental variables into the conditional likelihood. In this particular situation, known as ‘posterior adjustment,’ Eqs. (1) and (2) incorporate the covariate vector x, which comprises both the single bird-species variable and the environmental variables.

sec.title: Constructing a global risk score (GRS) of multiple species of wild birds
sec.p: According to the conditional likelihood analysis, several significant bird species have been identified. However, two main issues arise. Firstly, the significance determinations rely on a statistical convention, specifically employing a p-value of 0.05 as the threshold for significance. Consequently, altering this threshold would lead to changes in the number or subset of significant variables, namely bird species. Secondly, while many individual bird species may not exhibit significance in separate analyses, we intend to estimate the cumulative impact of these birds as a collective entity on the outcomes in question. It would be overly simplistic to model “significance” solely based on a summary index, such as the total count of birds or a measure of diversity. This prompted us to develop a GRS of multiple species of wild birds as an indicator of the likelihood of an avian influenza outbreak within a geographical area. Using the conditional likelihood approach, various threshold configurations for the p-value, acting as a variable-selection criterion, yield different subsets of explanatory variables (X). Subsequently, a risk score is formulated by selecting a linear combination of Xs (birds) with the highest predictive capability through conventional logistic regression and receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis. To expand the list of high-risk bird species and derive the corresponding risk score, we undertook several steps detailed in the second part of the Appendix 1.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Figure 2 (left panel) shows the geographic distribution with the observed frequency of the pacific golden plover based on the data obtained from the eBird Taiwan dataset. The predicted occupancy of the Pacific golden plover based on ZIP model as described in Step 1 of the Method section was coherent with the observed distribution (Fig. 2 right panel). The geographical distribution of the remaining 67 distinct wild bird species, which were chosen for this study, can be accessed on the webpage (aiv.nchu.edu.tw).

caption.p: (Left panel) Observed and (Right panel) estimated frequency of Pluvialis-Fulva (Pacific golden plover), based on a zero-inflated Poisson model.

sec.p: Next, 68 distinct wild bird species were individually matched as described in Step 2 of the Method section to individually estimate their associations with HPAI outbreaks on poultry farms, with or without adjustment of environmental factors. Tables 1 and Table 2 present odds ratio estimates computed from the conditional likelihood of Eqs. (1) and (2). Among 68 species analyzed, 11 demonstrated significant associations with HPAIV poultry farm outbreaks. These significant associations were identified in both conventional matching and counter-matching, for the scenarios of ‘without adjustment’ (Table 1) and ‘with prior adjustment’ (Table 2) for environmental factors. In both tables, columns 1 and 2 display the outcomes of 1:3 and 1:5 conventional matching, while columns 3 and 4 depict the results of counter-matching. Compared to the bootstrapped McNemar statistic as shown in column 5, as published by Wu et al.14two more wild bird species were identified with significant association with HPAIV poultry farm outbreaks, including Caspian tern, and peregrine falcon.

Among 11 wild bird species shown in Table 1, the black-headed gull exhibits highly significant odds ratios (OR) ranging from 3.93 to 4.86 for the two matching designs. With the inclusion of prior adjustment (Table 2), the OR estimates expand to a range of (4.65, 6.90). In contrast, with posterior adjustment as reported in the last column of Table 3, the OR is 4.48 (95% confidence interval (CI):1.23–16.32). It’s worth noting that in the case of posterior adjustment, we do not include environmental factors during the propensity score matching stage. These OR estimates are closely aligned, indicating coherent results. Another highly significant species to note is the long-toed stint. Its odds ratio estimates range from 1.63 to 2.48 for the two matching scenarios, both with and without prior adjustment. Additionally, when posterior adjustment is employed, the odds ratio remains significant, which equals 1.67 (95% CI: 1.03–2.70) (Table 3).

caption.p: Conditional likelihood estimates of environmental factors specific to the bird species which have significant association reported in Table 1. The estimates are reported under the consideration of posterior adjustment for land-cover (environmental) factors.

tr.th: odds ratios of 8 terrestrial factors(P value)

table-wrap-foot.p: farmland (FL), dry farming (DF), agricultural wetland (AW), forest (FR), wetland (WL), urban (UB), waterbody(WB), bushes (BU).
Indicate the estimates of bird itself shown at the first column under scientific name.

sec.p: In a broader context of how the matched controls were selected, the Pacific golden plover, Little grebe, Caspian tern, Pintail duck, Little tern, Common snipe, House swallow, Peregrine falcon, and Black-winged stilt also display a notable association with AIV outbreaks, with or without prior adjustments of the environmental factors. However, the significance of this association with AIV outbreaks in the Pacific golden plover, Pintail duck, Common snipe, House swallow, and Black-winged stilt may diminish when posterior adjustments are applied as shown in Table 3. Conversely, the Peregrine falcon exhibits increased significance after undergoing posterior adjustment. This shift in significance suggests potential confounding effects of environmental and terrestrial variables on the association with the outbreaks.

caption.p: Plot of area under the curve (AUC) versus p-value. The AUC increases with p-value. Dotted line: the migratory bird species only. Solid line: the migratory and residential bird species. The arrow indicates the elbow point.

sec.p: Finally, the two ROC curves (those with and without environmental factors adjustment) calculated for migratory birds only are displayed in Fig. 4 (left panel) with the AUC equal to 0.74 (without adjustment) and 0.80 (with adjustment). For the “with-adjustment” case, the GRS of the migratory bird species contributing to the poultry farm outbreaks was 0.306, which corresponds to the Youden index with a sensitivity equal to 0.74 and specificity equal to 0.74. When resident bird species were further considered, this risk score produced ROC curves with AUCs of 0.82 (without adjustment) and 0.84 (with adjustment), shown in Fig. 4 (right panel). The GRS, a linear combination of 27 migratory species and 27 resident species, was 0.320, and the Youden index cut-off (with-adjustment case) gives a sensitivity of 0.81 and specificity of 0.77. The supplementary table in Appendix 3 also lists these 27 resident bird species.

caption.p: ROC curves based on a global risk score. Left panel: only migratory bird species were considered; right panel: migratory and residential bird species were both included. Solid blue line: without adjustment of environmental factors; dashed brown line: with adjustment.

sec.title: Discussions
sec.p: The unique epidemiological pattern of clade 2.3.4.4 HPAI H5 is potentially shaped by eco-evolutionary processes through (i) the interaction between the viruses and a wide range of wild birds; (ii) the continued selection for both higher transmissibility and virulence, as observed in ducks36–39 or recently in milk cows40. It is necessary to enhance global surveillance and improve the understanding of the ecological properties that contribute to and sustain the transmission of HPAIV in wild birds such as species composition, population size, and demographic migration patterns. Polygenic risk scores (PRS) are becoming an increasingly popular approach to predict complex disease risk by deriving weighted scores after summing the number of risk increasing variants that participants harbour41. With the complexity of different wild bird species interacting with the poultry farms, the PRS framework motivates us to construct a poly-species GRS to summarize the avian influenza-associated wild bird species profile in the increasing large-scale population-level AIV-associated poultry farm outbreaks. Our study provides a robust approach to investigate the risk at the interface of domestic and wild birds. The high prediction accuracy of the GRS greater than 80% suggested its potential in outbreak prediction and implementing targeted surveillance.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We are thankful for the coding and computing works by Yen-Yi Chan and Chao-Hsuan Chang. This work is additionally supported by the grant “MOST 111-2118-M-005-003” from The National Science and Technology Council of Taiwan. The funding source of this study had no role in the study design, data collection, data analysis, data interpretation, or writing of the report. The corresponding author had full access to all data in the study and final responsibility for the decision to submit for publication. The authors declare no conflict of interest of any form that might be perceived to influence the results or discussion reported in this paper.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: HDW formed the concept and performed the analysis for the tables and figures. DYC provided the data and conceptualized the framework. Both HDW and DYC co-wrote the manuscript.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The datasets generated and/or analyzed during the current study are available in the open repository (aiv.nchu.edu.tw), except the dataset of poultry farms and HPAI outbreak farms due to the privacy of individual farm locations. However, the dataset of poultry farms and HPAI outbreak farms could be accessed by requesting the corresponding author. All experimental protocols for the identification of poultry farm-related data were approved and carried out in accordance with relevant guidelines and regulations of the Council of Agriculture, Taiwan.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
